awd_titl_txt: EAGER:Collaborative Research:Innovating technologies to inform synthetic plant metabolism through a new understanding of the cellular protein machinery
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant metabolism is a high priority target for synthetic biology, with significant potential to address global challenges ranging from food production to energy and the environment. However, the successful application of synthetic biology strategies in complex eukaryotes faces unique challenges. In particular, large gaps remain in the knowledge of how cellular processes are controlled at the nanoscale, which is an essential component of engineering design. The project will develop new electron microscopy-based strategies to visualize and create structural models of labile protein complexes captured from plant cells. Ultra-sensitive methods will be established to rigorously identify the protein components of these complexes using advanced proteomics and in planta validation techniques. This will establish a critical new framework for synthetic metabolism. The project will also create a unique interdisciplinary/inter-institution training environment at Virginia Tech and Pennsylvania State University that will engage students at all levels of education.

This interdisciplinary project will enable the study of dynamic multi-enzyme complexes in plants. A new integrated platform will be established for characterizing protein assemblies in the act of performing their biological functions in the uniquely-complex cellular environment of the plant cell. This suite of technologies will integrate advanced electron microscopy, proteomics, and 3D modeling capabilities to enable the nanoscale-level interrogation and understanding of the large, dynamic assemblies of proteins that define cellular biochemistry, and ultimately physiological function. The plant specialized pathway leading to flavonoids, a long-standing target for synthetic biology, will serve as the experimental model. This will generate outcomes that can be readily validated in planta and serve as a template the study of other biochemical systems. Altogether, the work will create a powerful new capability to address a critical information gap in current synthetic biology design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
For centuries, scientists have sought to understand the minute components that govern life's processes. To satisfy this curiosity, powerful instruments such as electron microscopes were invented, capable of revealing exquisite details of atomic entities. Using these state-of-the-art tools, researchers can now investigate never-before-seen pathogens that threaten human health or cause global pandemics. To complement the current "resolution revolution" that is sweeping the cryo-Electron Microscopy (EM) field, new materials and tools are needed to advance the next-generation of discoveries. As interest in high-resolution imaging has skyrocketed in the last decade, Liquid-EM, the room-temperature counterpart to cryo-EM, has quickly become a premier technique to analyze macromolecules live in solution. This unique perspective provides an excellent complement to other structural biology techniques 

Our microchip-based technology, developed during year 1 and 2 of the performance period permitted up to capture small, flexible protein assemblies for high-resoltuion structural analysis. This work occurred during the early days of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. As a much needed resource for the scientific community, we applied the microchip-based immunoprecipitation protocols to study proteins related to COVID-19. As work shifted during the pandemic, so did some of our time and resources.

 Recent advances made by our team include new computational tools to analyze movies of biological events in solution. Work with our collaborators led to the first high-resolution structures determined by Liquid-EM. Results revealed new dynamic views of adeno-associated virus subtype 3 (AAV), an important gene therapy vector and COVID-19 vaccine candidate. Individual protomers that comprised the virus capsid (VP1) showed similar features to the x-ray crystal structure at a resolution of ~3.22-Angstrom. AAV specimens prepared using cryo-EM exhibited only one main structure in the data population. In contrast, multiple dynamic structures were extracted from the liquid-EM movie data. These changes were attributed to Brownian motion, conformational movements, and natural dynamics. This breakthrough analysis demonstrated that protein assemblies were stable in solution during extending timeframes, and that high-resolution features were preserved in a liquid environment. This achievement has been long sought-after, since physiologically relevant changes cannot be easily achieved with frozen specimens.

As a complement to these dynamic technical discoveries, during year 3 of the performance period, we employed microchip technology to determine the first high-resolution structure of the SARS-CoV-2 Nucleocapsid protein. Interestingly, the ancestral protein structure is about 99% conserved across all variants of concern. The structural findings of this work helped to conceptually develop the first rapid antigen test, commonly used for at home-testing, worldwide. 

While additional studies for plant protein assemblies are ongoing at our performance site, the technology developments resulting during the funding period are of high impact for the scientific community.


Last Modified: 01/03/2023
Modified by: Deborah F Kelly
